4.5.2. A grazing set that is $C^{1}$ but not twice differentiable for incoming spherical waves. Take $F(u, v)=1-G(u, v)$, where $G(u, v)=u^{4}+v^{4}$. The incoming phase is $\phi_{i}=$ $-t+|x-b|$, where $b=(1,-1,0)$. Here again $\underline{\sigma}=i^{*}(1,0, t, 0,-\bar{b},-1) \in G_{d}^{4} \backslash G^{5}$. In this case $-G$ is strictly concave but the assumption (4.8) of Theorem 6 fails; we only have $-\nabla^{2} G \geq 0$ for $(u, v) \neq 0$. The grazing curve is now

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{H}(u, v)=3\left(u^{4}+v^{4}\right)+4 u^{3}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow u=-3^{1 / 3} v^{4 / 3}(4+3 u)^{-1 / 3} \Rightarrow u \sim v^{4 / 3} \text { for }(u, v) \text { near } 0
\end{aligned}
$$

One checks as in $\S 4.5 .1$ that this equation determines $u$ as a function of $v$ near $(u, v)=0$. The second line of (4.40) implies $u^{\prime}(0)=0$ and the implicit function theorem shows that in $v \neq 0$ the function $u(v)$ is $C^{1}$, so now we have $u(v)$ is differentiable near $v=0$.

To see that $u$ is $C^{1}$ near $v=0$ rewrite $\mathcal{H}(u, v)=0$ as $u\left(4 u^{2}+3 u^{3}\right)=-3 v^{4}$ and differentiate with respect to $v$ obtaining

$$
u^{\prime}\left(4 u^{2}+3 u^{3}\right)+u\left(8 u u^{\prime}+9 u^{2} u^{\prime}\right)=u^{\prime}\left(12 u^{2}+12 u^{3}\right)=-12 v^{3}
$$

For $v \neq 0$ small divide by $12 u^{2}+12 u^{3}$ and use (4.40) to see that

$$
\left|u^{\prime}(v)\right| \sim\left|v^{3} / u^{2}\right| \sim v^{1 / 3}
$$

Thus $u$ is $C^{1}$ near 0 .
From (4.42) it is clear that the limit defining $u^{\prime \prime}(0)$ does not exist. We can get more information by differentiating (4.41) with respect to $v$ to obtain

$$
\left|u^{\prime \prime}(v)\right| \sim v^{-2 / 3} \text { for } v \neq 0
$$

Remark 4.12. In the above example the function $g(u, v)$ as in (4.12) is

$$
g(u, v)=4 u^{3}=\left.v^{3} \tilde{g}(z)\right|_{z=\frac{u}{v}}, \text { where } \tilde{g}(z)=4 z^{3}
$$

so $\tilde{g}$ now has a triple root. This and the failure of $\zeta=u-u(v)$ to be $C^{\infty}$ (or even $C^{2}$ ) reflect the fact that $\nabla^{2}\left(u^{4}+v^{4}\right)$ fails to be positive definite for $(u, v) \neq 0$; it is only positive semidefinite for $(u, v) \neq 0$.

To conclude $\S 4$ we return for a moment to the case of incoming plane waves to provide a couple of examples we had not found at the time of writing of [WW23].
4.5.3. A cusped grazing set for incoming plane waves. Take $F(u, v)=1-G(u, v)$, where $G(u, v)=u^{4}+2 u^{2} v^{2}+u v^{2}+v^{2}$. The incoming phase is $\phi_{i}=-t+(u, v) \cdot \bar{\theta}$, where $\bar{\theta}=(1,0)$. The point

$$
\underline{\sigma}=i^{*}(1,0, t, 0, \bar{\theta},-1) \in G_{d}^{4} \backslash G^{5}
$$

and $\nabla^{2} G(u, v)>0$ for $(u, v) \neq 0$. When the source is at infinity the grazing curve is defined by $\nabla G(u, v) \cdot \bar{\theta}=G_{u}=0$ instead of (4.10). In this case we obtain

$$
v^{2}+4 u v^{2}+4 u^{3}=0 ; \text { that is } 4 u^{3}=-v^{2}(1+4 u)
$$

4.5.4. A grazing set that is $C^{1}$ but not twice differentiable for incoming plane waves. Here is an example where the GS assumption holds just barely. Take $F(u, v)=1-$ $G(u, v)$, where $G(u, v)=u^{4}+u v^{4}+u^{2} v^{4}+v^{2}$. The incoming phase is $\phi_{i}=-t+(u, v) \cdot \bar{\theta}$, where $\bar{\theta}=(1,0)$. Here again $\underline{\sigma} \in G_{d}^{4} \backslash G^{5}$ and $\nabla^{2} G(u, v)>0$ for $(u, v) \neq 0$. In this case the grazing curve is

$$
G_{u}=4 u^{3}+v^{4}+2 u v^{4}=0 \Rightarrow 4 u^{3}=-v^{4}(1+2 u) \Rightarrow u=4^{-1 / 3} v^{4 / 3}+O\left(v^{8 / 3}\right)
$$

so $|u| \sim|v|^{4 / 3}$. This is similar to (4.40). The same analysis shows that the grazing curve is $C^{1}$ but not $C^{2}$ near $(u, v)=0$. See Figure 2.

# 5. THE REFLECTED FLOW MAP FOR GENERAL CONVEX INCOMING WAVES 

We show in this section that the computations of section 3 can be generalized to a larger class of incoming waves. Suppose $\mathcal{O}$ is a convex obstacle given by

$$
\mathcal{O}:=\left\{\left(x_{1}, \bar{x}\right) \mid x_{1}<F(\bar{x}), \bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n-1}\right\}
$$

where $F: \mathbb{R}^{n-1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is a $C^{\infty}$ strictly concave function. We can arrange by translation and rotation of $\mathcal{O}$ so that $F$ has a max at $\bar{x}=0$ with $F(0)=1$. The tangent plane to $\partial \mathcal{O}$ at $\left(x_{1}, \bar{x}\right)=(1,0)$ is then $x_{1}=1$.

We consider incoming phases of the form

$$
\phi_{i}(x)=-t+\psi_{i}(x),\left(\partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}\right)^{2}+\left|\nabla \psi_{i}\right|^{2}=1
$$

where $\psi_{i}$ is a convex function. In what follows the notation $\nabla$ always means $\nabla_{\bar{x}}$.
Assumption 5.1. Let $F$ and $\mathcal{O}$ be as just described. Assume there exists $r>0$, an $\mathbb{R}^{n}$-open set $\Omega \ni(1,0)$, and a $C^{\infty}$ function $\psi: \Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { (a) } \Omega \cap \partial \mathcal{O}=\{(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}): \bar{x} \in B(0, r)\} \\
& \text { (b) }\left|\nabla \psi_{i}\right|=1 \text { and } \psi_{i} \text { is convex on } \Omega
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark. We can obtain a large supply of functions $\psi_{i}$ satisfying the conditions of Assumption 5.1 as follows. Let $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ be any open convex set with $C^{\infty}$ boundary $\partial \mathcal{C}$. It is well-known that the distance-to-the-boundary function $\psi_{i}(x)=-\operatorname{dist}(x, \partial C)$ is smooth, convex, and satisfies $\left|\nabla \psi_{i}\right|=1$ for points of $\mathcal{C}$ sufficiently near $\partial \mathcal{C}$. When $\partial \mathcal{C}$ is a plane, the incoming waves determined by (5.1) are plane waves; when $\partial \mathcal{C}$ is a sphere, the incoming waves are spherical waves, and so on.

If the incoming bicharacteristics $\gamma_{i}$ hit the cotangent bundle on the space-time boundary at $\left(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}, t, \xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x}), \bar{\xi}^{i}(\bar{x}),-1\right)$, then there must hold

$$
\xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x})=\partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}), \bar{\xi}^{i}(\bar{x})=\nabla \psi_{i}(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x})
$$

The grazing set and the illuminable set are

$$
G_{\phi_{i}}=\left\{(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}, t) \mid\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}, \nabla F\right\rangle-\xi_{1}^{i}=0\right\}, I_{-}=\left\{(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}, t) \mid\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}, \nabla F\right\rangle-\xi_{1}^{i}>0\right\}
$$

Fix any $T>0$ and any $r_{1}<r$ for $r$ as in Assumption 5.1. In (5.3) and the rest of this section we take $\bar{x} \in \overline{B\left(0, r_{1}\right)}$ and $t \in[-T, T]$.
Lemma 5.2. Let $\Psi(\bar{x}):=\psi_{i}(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x})$. If the incoming phase satisfies Assumption 5.1, then:

1. The matrix

$$
\nabla^{2} \Psi-\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla^{2} F=\frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}+\nabla F \otimes \nabla \xi_{1}^{i}
$$

is symmetric and positive semi-definite.
2. The incoming directions $\xi^{i}$ are non-focusing: for $\bar{x}^{*}, \bar{x}$ in the $\bar{x}$-projection of $G_{\phi_{i}} \cup I$, the following holds

$$
\left\langle\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right), \xi^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi^{i}(\bar{x})\right\rangle \geq 0
$$

Proof. 1. We have $\nabla \Psi=\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F+\bar{\xi}^{i}$. Differentiate this to obtain the given identity. On the other hand a direct computation shows

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla^{2} \Psi & =\left(\partial_{x_{1}}^{2} \psi_{i}\right) \nabla F \otimes \nabla F+\nabla F \otimes \nabla \partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}+\nabla \partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i} \otimes \nabla F+\nabla^{2} \psi_{i}+\left(\partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}\right) \nabla^{2} F \\
& =\left(\left(\nabla F\right)^{T} I\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\partial_{x_{1}}^{2} \psi_{i} & \nabla \partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i} \\
\left(\nabla \partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}\right)^{T} & \nabla^{2} \psi_{i}
\end{array}\right)\binom{\nabla F}{I}+\left(\partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}\right) \nabla^{2} F
\end{aligned}
$$

The result follows since the first matrix on the right is symmetric and positive semidefinite.
2. Using the formula $\xi^{i}(\bar{x})=\left(\partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}, \nabla \psi_{i}\right)(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x})$ and the convexity of $\psi_{i}$, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right), \xi^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi^{i}(\bar{x})\right\rangle \\
& =-\left\langle\left(\partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}, \nabla \psi_{i}\right)\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \bar{x}^{*}\right),\left(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}\right)-\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \bar{x}^{*}\right)\right\rangle \\
& -\left\langle\left(\partial_{x_{1}} \psi_{i}, \nabla \psi_{i}\right)(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}),\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \bar{x}^{*}\right)-(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x})\right\rangle \\
& \geq-\left(\psi_{i}\left(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}\right)-\psi_{i}\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \bar{x}^{*}\right)\right)-\left(\psi_{i}\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \bar{x}^{*}\right)-\psi_{i}(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x})\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

This completes the proof.
Let $\xi^{r}(\bar{x})$ be the reflected covector field on the boundary, then

$$
\xi^{r}-\xi^{i}=c(1,-\nabla F),\left|\xi^{r}\right|=1
$$

From here we solve

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \xi_{1}^{r}=\xi_{1}^{i}-\frac{2}{1+|\nabla F|^{2}}\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}, \nabla F\right\rangle\right) \\
& \bar{\xi}^{r}=\bar{\xi}^{i}+\frac{2 \nabla F}{1+|\nabla F|^{2}}\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}, \nabla F\right\rangle\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We obtain the following identities from (5.4):

$$
\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F+\bar{\xi}^{i}=\xi_{1}^{r} \nabla F+\bar{\xi}^{r}, \xi_{1}^{r}-\left\langle\nabla F, \bar{\xi}^{r}\right\rangle=-\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}, \nabla F\right\rangle\right)
$$

The reflected flow map is then given by

$$
Z_{r}(s, \bar{x}, t)=(F(\bar{x})+2 s \xi_{1}^{r}(\bar{x}), \bar{x}+2 s \bar{\xi}^{r}(\bar{x}), t+2 s) \text { for } s \in[0, \infty), \bar{x} \in B(0, r), t \in \mathbb{R}
$$

Proposition 5.3. Fix any $s_{0}>0$. The reflected flow map $Z_{r}$ is a diffeomorphism from $\left[0, s_{0}\right] \times I_{-}$onto its range and extends to a homeomorphism from $\left[0, s_{0}\right] \times\left(G_{\phi_{t}} \cup I_{-}\right)$ onto its range.

Proof. Injectivity. It suffices to show that

$$
z(s, \bar{x}):=(F(\bar{x}), \bar{x})+2 s \xi^{r}(\bar{x})
$$

is injective from the $(s, \bar{x})$-projection of $G_{\phi_{t}} \cup I_{-}$to its range. Suppose the contrary, then there exists $(s, \bar{x}) \neq\left(s^{*}, \bar{x}^{*}\right)$ in the $(s, \bar{x})$-projection of $G_{\phi_{t}} \cup I_{-}$such that ${ }^{28}$

$$
z(s, \bar{x})=z\left(s^{*}, \bar{x}^{*}\right), \text { i.e., }\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right)=2 s \xi^{r}(\bar{x})-2 s^{*} \xi^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)
$$

Using the second equation in (5.6) we find

$$
\left\langle\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right), \xi^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi^{r}(\bar{x})\right\rangle=-2\left(s+s^{*}\right)\left(1-\left\langle\xi^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \xi^{r}(\bar{x})\right\rangle\right) \leq 0
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{28}$ This assumption implies $\bar{x} \neq \bar{x}^{*}$.

with equality holding if and only if

$$
\xi^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)=\xi^{r}(\bar{x})
$$

On the other hand, we show that for all $\bar{x}, \bar{x}^{*}$, there holds

$$
\left\langle\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right), \xi^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi^{r}(\bar{x})\right\rangle \geq 0
$$

with equality holding if and only if

$$
\begin{gathered}
\xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x})-\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}(\bar{x}), \nabla F(\bar{x})\right\rangle=\xi_{1}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \nabla F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)\right\rangle=0, \text { and } \\
\left\langle\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right), \xi^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi^{i}(\bar{x})\right\rangle=0
\end{gathered}
$$

Indeed, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right), \xi^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi^{r}(\bar{x})\right\rangle \\
& \stackrel{(5.5)}{=}\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x})\right)\left(\xi_{1}^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi_{1}^{r}(\bar{x})\right)+\left\langle\bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}, \bar{\xi}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\bar{\xi}^{i}(\bar{x})\right\rangle \\
& \quad+\left(\xi_{1}^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi_{1}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)\right)\left\langle\nabla F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \bar{x}-\bar{x}^{*}\right\rangle+\left(\xi_{1}^{r}(\bar{x})-\xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x})\right)\left\langle\nabla F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right\rangle \\
& \geq\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x})\right)\left(\xi_{1}^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi_{1}^{r}(\bar{x})\right)+\left\langle\bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}, \bar{\xi}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\bar{\xi}^{i}(\bar{x})\right\rangle \\
& \quad+\left(\xi_{1}^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi_{1}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)\right)\left(F(\bar{x})-F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)\right)+\left(\xi_{1}^{r}(\bar{x})-\xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x})\right)\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x})\right) \\
& =\left\langle\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right), \xi^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi^{i}(\bar{x})\right\rangle \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Here we used (5.4) and the definition of $G_{\phi_{t}} \cup I_{-}$, which imply that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\xi_{1}^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi_{1}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right) & =\frac{2}{1+\left|\nabla F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)\right|^{2}}\left(\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \nabla F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)\right\rangle-\xi_{1}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)\right) \geq 0 \\
\xi_{1}^{r}(\bar{x})-\xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x}) & =\frac{2}{1+|\nabla F(\bar{x})|^{2}}\left(\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}(\bar{x}), \nabla F(\bar{x})\right\rangle-\xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x})\right) \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $F$ is strictly concave, with (5.12) we conclude that overall equality holds in (5.11) if and only if

$$
\begin{gathered}
\xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x})-\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}(\bar{x}), \nabla F(\bar{x})\right\rangle=\xi_{1}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right), \nabla F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)\right\rangle=0, \text { and } \\
\left\langle\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right), \xi^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-\xi^{i}(\bar{x})\right\rangle=0
\end{gathered}
$$

Combining (5.7) and (5.9), we conclude that (5.8) and (5.10) must be true. The first condition in (5.10), (5.4), and (5.8) together imply that

$$
\xi^{i}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)=\xi^{r}\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)=\xi^{r}(\bar{x})=\xi^{i}(\bar{x})
$$

This and (5.6) give

$$
\left(F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right)=2\left(s-s^{*}\right) \xi^{i}(\bar{x})
$$

From (5.10) we have $\xi_{1}^{i}(\bar{x})=\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}(\bar{x}), \nabla F(\bar{x})\right\rangle$. Multiplying this equation by $2\left(s-s^{*}\right)$ and using (5.14), we obtain

$$
F\left(\bar{x}^{*}\right)-F(\bar{x})=\left\langle\nabla F(\bar{x}), \bar{x}^{*}-\bar{x}\right\rangle
$$

Since $F$ is strictly concave, this can be true only if $\bar{x}=\bar{x}^{*}$, which implies that $(s, \bar{x})=$ $\left(s^{*}, \bar{x}^{*}\right)$ by (5.6). This contradicts the assumption.

The map $Z_{r}$ is continuous and injective on the compact domain $\left[0, s_{0}\right] \times\left(G_{\phi_{t}} \cup I_{-}\right)$, and hence is a homeomorphism on this domain.

Diffeomorphism. Recall that

$$
A=I-\frac{\bar{\xi}^{r} \otimes \nabla F}{\xi_{1}^{r}}+2 s\left(\frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\partial \bar{x}}-\frac{\bar{\xi}^{r} \otimes \nabla \xi_{1}^{r}}{\xi_{1}^{r}}\right)
$$

Differentiating $\left|\xi^{r}\right|^{2}=1$ we find

$$
A=I-\frac{\bar{\xi}^{r} \otimes \nabla F}{\xi_{1}^{r}}+2 s\left(I+\frac{\bar{\xi}^{r} \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\left(\xi_{1}^{r}\right)^{2}}\right) \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\partial \bar{x}}
$$

Recalling (5.5), we differentiate

$$
\bar{\xi}^{r}=\bar{\xi}^{i}+\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right) \nabla F
$$

to obtain

$$
\frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\partial \bar{x}}=\frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}+\nabla F \otimes \nabla\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right)+\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right) \nabla^{2} F
$$

Differentiate the defining formula (5.4) of $\xi_{1}^{r}$ to find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right) & =2 \frac{\nabla \xi_{1}^{i}-\nabla F \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\partial \bar{x}}-\bar{\xi}^{i} \nabla^{2} F}{1+|\nabla F|^{2}}-2 \frac{\bar{\xi}^{r}-\bar{\xi}^{i}}{1+|\nabla F|^{2}} \nabla^{2} F \\
& =-2 \frac{\bar{\xi}^{i}+\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F}{\xi_{1}^{i}\left(1+|\nabla F|^{2}\right)} \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}-\frac{2 \bar{\xi}^{r} \nabla^{2} F}{1+|\nabla F|^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\partial \bar{x}} & =\frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}-\frac{2 \nabla F \otimes\left(\bar{\xi}^{i}+\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F\right)}{\xi_{1}^{i}\left(1+|\nabla F|^{2}\right)} \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}-\frac{2}{1+|\nabla F|^{2}}\left(\nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}\right) \nabla^{2} F+\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right) \nabla^{2} F \\
& =\left(I-\frac{2 \nabla F \otimes\left(\bar{\xi}^{i}+\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F\right)}{\xi_{1}^{i}\left(1+|\nabla F|^{2}\right)}\right) \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}+\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right)\left(I-\frac{2 \nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\left(1+|\nabla F|^{2}\right)\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right)}\right) \nabla^{2} F
\end{aligned}
$$

In the following we denote

$$
\begin{aligned}
& B:=I-\frac{\bar{\xi}^{r} \otimes \nabla F}{\xi_{1}^{r}}, C:=I+\frac{\bar{\xi}^{r} \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\left(\xi_{1}^{r}\right)^{2}} \\
& K:=\left(I-\frac{2 \nabla F \otimes\left(\bar{\xi}^{i}+\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F\right)}{\xi_{1}^{i}\left(1+|\nabla F|^{2}\right)}\right) \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}} \\
& L:=\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right)\left(I-\frac{2 \nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\left(1+|\nabla F|^{2}\right)\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right)}\right) \nabla^{2} F
\end{aligned}
$$

This allows us to rewrite $A$ as in (5.15) as

$$
A=B+2 s C \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\partial \bar{x}}=B+2 s C(K+L)=B\left[I+2 s B^{-1} C\left(B^{-1}\right)^{T}\left(B^{T} K+B^{T} L\right)\right]
$$

We compute

$$
B^{T} K=\left(I-\frac{\nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\xi_{1}^{r}}-\frac{2 \nabla F \otimes\left(\bar{\xi}^{i}+\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F\right)}{\xi_{1}^{i}\left(1+|\nabla F|^{2}\right)}+\frac{2\left(\bar{\xi}^{r}, \nabla F\right) \nabla F \otimes\left(\bar{\xi}^{i}+\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F\right)}{\xi_{1}^{i} \xi_{1}^{r}\left(1+|\nabla F|^{2}\right)}\right) \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}
$$

By the definition of $\bar{\xi}^{r}(5.4)$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{r}, \nabla F\right\rangle & =\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}, \nabla F\right\rangle+|\nabla F|^{2}\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right) \\
& =\frac{1+|\nabla F|^{2}}{2}\left(\xi_{1}^{r}-\xi_{1}^{i}\right)+|\nabla F|^{2}\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right)+\xi_{1}^{i} \\
& =\frac{1+|\nabla F|^{2}}{2} \xi_{1}^{i}+\frac{1-|\nabla F|^{2}}{2} \xi_{1}^{r}
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies ${ }^{29}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
B^{T} K & =\left(I-\frac{\nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\xi_{1}^{r}}+\frac{\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}}{\xi_{1}^{i} \xi_{1}^{r}} \nabla F \otimes\left(\bar{\xi}^{i}+\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F\right)\right) \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}} \\
& =\left(I+\frac{\nabla F \otimes\left(\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right) \nabla F-\bar{\xi}^{r}\right)}{\xi_{1}^{i}}\right) \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}} \\
& =\left(I-\frac{\nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\xi_{1}^{i}}\right) \frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}=\frac{\partial \bar{\xi}^{i}}{\partial \bar{x}}+\nabla F \otimes \nabla \xi_{1}^{i}=\nabla^{2} \Psi-\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla^{2} F
\end{aligned}
$$

Now apply Lemma 5.2 to see that $B^{T} K$ is symmetric and positive semi-definite.
We now simplify $B^{T} L$. Notice that

$$
\left(B^{-1}\right)^{T}=I+\frac{\nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\xi_{1}^{r}-\left\langle\nabla F, \bar{\xi}^{r}\right\rangle}=I-\frac{\nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\xi_{1}^{i}-\left\langle\nabla F, \bar{\xi}^{i}\right\rangle}
$$

On the other hand, using the definition (5.4) of $\xi_{1}^{r}$, we have

$$
L=\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right)\left(I-\frac{\nabla F \otimes \bar{\xi}^{r}}{\xi_{1}^{i}-\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{r}, \nabla F\right\rangle}\right) \nabla^{2} F=\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right) B^{-T} \nabla^{2} F
$$

Thus we have

$$
B^{T} L=\left(\xi_{1}^{i}-\xi_{1}^{r}\right) \nabla^{2} F \geq 0
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{29}$ To obtain the second equality in (5.16), use (5.5) to replace $\bar{\xi}^{i}+\xi_{1}^{i} \nabla F$ by $\bar{\xi}^{r}+\xi_{1}^{r} \nabla F$.

Arguing as in the case of spherical waves, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
j(s, \bar{x}, t) & =2 \xi_{1}^{r} \operatorname{det} A=2 \xi_{1}^{r} \operatorname{det}(B) \operatorname{det}\left(I+2 s B^{-1} C(K+L)\right) \\
& =2\left(\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}, \nabla F\right\rangle-\xi_{1}^{i}\right) \operatorname{det}\left(I+2 s B^{-1} C\left(B^{-1}\right)^{T}\left(B^{T} K+B^{T} L\right)\right) \\
& \geq 2\left(\left\langle\bar{\xi}^{i}, \nabla F\right\rangle-\xi_{1}^{i}\right)>0
\end{aligned}
$$

This completes the proof.

abstract:
In a recent paper [WW23] we studied the transport of oscillations in
solutions to linear and some semilinear second-order hyperbolic boundary
problems along rays that graze a convex obstacle to any order. We showed that
high frequency exact solutions are well approximated in $H^1$ by much simpler
approximate solutions constructed from explicit solutions to profile equations.
That result depends on two geometric assumptions, referred to here as the
grazing set (GS) and reflected flow map (RFM) assumptions, that are both
difficult to verify in general. The GS assumption states that the grazing set,
that is, the set of points on the spacetime boundary at which incoming
characteristics meet the boundary tangentially, is a codimension two, $C^1$
submanifold of spacetime. The second is that the reflected flow map, which
sends points on the spacetime boundary forward in time to points on reflected
and grazing rays, is injective and has appropriate regularity properties near
the grazing set. In this paper we analyze these assumptions for incoming plane,
spherical, and more general ``convex waves" when the governing hyperbolic
operator is the wave operator $\Box:=\Delta-\partial_t^2$. We prove general
results describing when the assumptions hold, and provide explicit examples
where the GS assumption fails.
